cons: Are u kidding me? There are zero cons. Amazon rules. Todd Bavol makes sure of it. This guy should be promoted.
advice: Promote Todd Bavol. This man can single handedly take this company and expand it. He can do so many great things. He's a sweet person, just a nice guy. And he's intelligible. Promote the man.
pros: Amazon is honestly the greatest place to work if you're looking for a warehouse job. They literally give you on the spot jobs and the service is incredible. Speak to Todd Bavol. He will hook you up with a job so fast that your head will spin. He's a great guy and amazon is fantastic. Greatest place to work on earth.

cons: Frugality sometimes edges into frupidity. The day-1 startup culture is sometimes at odds with an enterprise of that size and can make it hard to get things done.
advice: Continue to expand AWS, and work to ensure all employees are having the same positive experience that I have had to this point.
pros: Great culture, ability to tackle challenging problems at an unprecedented scale. Tons of opportunity for advancement if you put the work in.

cons: The work is too busy
pros: good experience here and good employer

cons: none at all just perfect
pros: great place to work nd benefit yourself

cons: Every team is different. I would suggest, experience it urself.I didn't find any cons
pros: Great learning opportunity, dynamic working environment, cooperative staff, fun environment

cons: There are very scrict safety rules and the work is fast paced.Many emplyees complain, because of the ssfety rules and that Amazon works them to hard.
pros: The management have really good attitude and it speads to the workers.The work is fast paced.You get crossed trained in many different areas and the managment tries and keeps you where you enjoy the most.The bonuses and benefits are very good.

cons: on call ; may have to tap in different area in short time . challenging but also beneficial for oneself
pros: good environments, fast move company. you have relative small groups to finish the task. the leadership principals are benefits

cons: NONE I enjoy working for the company and would love to move up in the corporation.
advice: NONE and to keep doing your job they provide bonuses and tons of positive feedback.
pros: Extremely fun job. You get a chance to be creative and promote a product, Amazon Student. You get experience managing inventory, social media accounts, and present and pitch Amazon to large crowds of people. Overall great experience!
summary: working at Amazon as Brand Ambassador

cons: On that $2,000, you'll be taxed $500! Also, When you expect that The Offer, that's it you know have become trash to them, So do not ask for a good reference becsue in the eyes of the Amazon you now become the bad person because you chose the offer. But you cant go back to Amazon ever. Great and Talented leadership style former employee cant even apply no more. The Offer SUKS bigtime. Watch Amazom formers do much bett… er elsewhere. for more money and a balanced wife-life (KUDOS to everyone who have helped me build this rating)
advice: Finally, the leadership is waking up to REAL Amazon. There are much better jobs out there. Only the disadvantaged stay behind leaving the better opportunities for the leaders who work smart and not harder. Family life and work life MUST mesh together or you will have extraordinary awesome employees leave such as myself and a few other extraordinaires that left Amazon FC (SAT1). Too bad. It's not about the money y'all… , it's the attitude --- Remember that. Treat your folks like the way you want to be treated. And watch y'all s labor hours go down. Watch the sleepy heads in the "each receive area", Some AMs love to take a snooze in the laptop cart. LaLaLalaaa Laaa LLLLaaaa Baba... sleeping away until I wask home and he smiles.LOL.(HR) Ditch them all and hire all new personnel. One of then olddies got me terminated because the young lady the know she completely lied to me about my time. and that happens a lot here because HR reps don't fully understand
pros: You made it through "Peak Season" now you've earned a great incentive! After around the first month of the year, "The Offer" will be made to you. One peak season and you've earned about $2,000! Go for it!! It's there awaiting for you just to sign for it.
summary: TAKE "THE OFFER" FOR A JOB WELL DONE

cons: Monotonous but still challenging, so not really a con.
pros: Great management, training, and environment.

cons: - Some departments operate differently than others, so make sure you pick the right one- Teams reinvent the wheel often- Cross team collaboration could be stronger
pros: - Focus on innovation- Ability to learn and grow- Very dynamic and open minded internal community
summary: Incredible opportunity to learn and be curious

cons: sometimes you will feel pressured
pros: it is a good place to work

cons: At time work becomes hectic but not always.Not every one get an awesome work.some teams are operationally heavy. so it depends on your luck.
advice: Increase the perks little more (medical coverage and bonus packages). try to reduce the operational load of the employee. please encourage to contribute back to open source society
pros: It is a highly competitive work environmentyou will work highly talented peopleyou will be working all the latest technologies

cons: - Pace can get tiring
advice: Keep doing what you are doing
pros: - Autonomous, fast paced and challenging- Professional and personal growth- Everyday learn something new

cons: Long Hours over the holidays
pros: Great Health insurance, dental and vision. Awesome stock options.

cons: The annual reviews were bureaucratic and the leveling system makes moving up a challenge.
advice: invest in your people more instead of thinking the answer is outside the organization
pros: Generous stock options. Fun corporate culture. Ability to learn a lot in the field.

cons: Lots of walking and on your feet.
advice: Organized and great
pros: The pay is pretty good. Fun cool people working there. Meet allot of people
summary: It's a humongous warehouse. They're all about safety. Hour ago by quickly because you always have work

cons: Have a good idea, be careful it might come true. Be sure to balance your workload and you will find great success
advice: Outstanding
pros: Excellent opportunity to lead large recruiting projects and teams! Career advancement opportunities like no where else and ability to create new initiatives

cons: You work long hours and there is a lot of time you have a high associate to manager ratio. But you get a support staff to help out.
advice: You are doing a fine job. Keep up the great work. You are pushing the company in the right direction.
pros: Great work environment. Leadership team is great to work for. They are very passionate about success. I would suggest it to anyone looking to be the best.

cons: Work can be hectic. As a manager, you have to take hold of your work life balance and not let the business overrun you.
advice: Continue supporting managers to do what they feel is right. Encourage stress relief practices and a healthy work life balance.
pros: Good company that supports its managers. You get out what you put in to the company. My managers encourage me to continue learning and I don't feel too much pressure from them for performance.

cons: Well the breaks don't seem like breaks, it feels like rushing to break just to sit down for maybe 5 minutes then rush back from break and for lunch you better know how to swalliw your food whole or chew extremely fast cause you might get 15 minutes to eat by the time you walk to the nreak room and heat up your food. Going to break and lunch is a lot more like running a 100 yard dash than actually taking a break.
advice: Give 2 20 minute breaks with a one minute grace period time and a a 45 minute lunch with a 3 minute grace period.
pros: Amazon us a great place to work and begin a wonderful career. They truly respect and greatly value their employees. It is challenging yet rewarding.

cons: Physically Demanding "Good work-life balance not always possible"
advice: Keep up the Good Work
pros: "Ability to learn a lot in the field"

cons: At times you have to work way to many hours, not enough rest in the day.
advice: None at this time.
pros: Money is good, friendly staff, job security

cons: There are practices related to the review process that make it difficult to get promoted. It's a very involved process and can be political in nature.
advice: I worked with very competent management and was happy with my experience. I really don't have anything to add here.
pros: Enjoyed the work environment. Very relaxed and allowed for work life balance. I worked for a fast paced piece of the business that allowed me to be directly involved in the growth of the company.

cons: * You are expected to be an owner, so you can get invested. This sometimes translates to long hours* Vacation policy is one of the worst* General benefits package is one of the worst (401k, maternity/paternity leave, etc.)
advice: Frugality is a word used heavily to excuse the lack of benefits offered to its valued employees. However, the lack of benefits can often drive engineers away. At that point, it's no longer frugal. HR policies need to be updated to the 21st century.
pros: * Work among talented, intelligent people* Work on exciting projects at the forefront of cloud development* Everyone is inspired and hard-working* Clear sense of company culture

cons: work/life balance is hard to adjust to
pros: Great Career opportunities and endless options

cons: Hours are long and deadlines are aggressive. Poor work/life balance but that seems to be the case with most high paying entry level college jobs.
advice: Spend more time training new hires.
pros: Great pay, amazing talent, and a sense of belonging. Your cohort wants to be there and there is a common vision to work towards making Amazon one of the most important businesses in the world.

cons: Getting the work done early, causes the lower paid (contract employees) to get sent home early.
advice: We (I'm a shift manager) need to stop with all this GOOD IDEA FAIRY crap. If it's not broken don't try to fix it. Can't recall how many times a new manager would come in and try to change everything, because they think their idea is the greatest thought since sliced bread. AMZ likes to higher new grads then place them in charge. The issue is the training they receive does not teach them how to manage people. Yes they…  understand how to process a package, but not how to get better productivity from employees. And on the contract employee, you need to STOP praying your badge will go from white to blue. You are a temp EMPLOYEE, and will get TERMINATED. IF you want a blue badge, submit an application to AMAZON not the warehouse temp agency. You are getting low wages because the temp agency needs to get paid too. Blaming AMZ for your pay is not AMZ problem, it's your temp agency. Fir those that complain about the rate you need to keep. There again blame the temp agency, they stated how much they belive they can get out of you. We did not hire you, your temp agency did. But I do agree, on the walk to and from breaks and lunch. On my shifts, I take care of my crews, and they get the job done. We are constantly informed how are production is in the top 1%.
pros: Love the pay (well over $20 an hour) even with out a degree, and zero warehouse experince.
summary: amazon pays a decent wage, but not your temp agency

cons: No Cons. I can't really think of any this is a great company to work for overall and is filled with great people.
advice: None
pros: Its a great company. Lots of benefits. Pay. Can maybe move up if you work hard enough. Makes me smile.

cons: Have to on call. The rotation time depends on the size and workload of team.Hard to get promotion. Slow growth of salary
advice: Provide a access to review direct manager to higher level manager. Manager is always open to hear problems and questions.
pros: In downtown seattle.Lots of food options for lunch and dinnerNice and clean working environment.Flexible working time.

cons: There are to many poor mae
advice: Pay more attention to helping managers.
pros: Great place to work and make a carrer

cons: Glassdoor is making me write this. This is annoying.
pros: Growing organization with exceptional employee focus.

cons: can't touch core business,
pros: helpful, can help to gain some industry experience

cons: there is a lot of stress involved in the job
advice: keep up the good work
pros: the company has a good work culture

cons: Always changing so some people can't keep up and quit. Seen good people leaving cause they can't follow the culture
advice: Keep rocking

cons: Poor benefits compared to the competition.
pros: Customer focus draws great employees.

cons: Work-life balance happens on a team-by-team basis. In addition to having to force your own schedule, you can end up on a team that works longer hours than others. This doesn't mean they necessarily get more, or less, work done. The opposite can also be true. There are many elements of 'getting lucky' when it comes to this one.It's not for everyone. If you're not able to infer from ambiguous data, rapidly lear… n new skillsets, and take on the right partners with ruthless efficiency, you will struggle. Some folks settle in to a particular role and never move up - but the unspoken policy is 'up or out'. That is to say, move up in your current role, or find a new one. This isn't inherently a bad thing, but means you need to be open to the idea of moving teams, or locations, often, if you don't end up where you wanted to be in short order.If you're someone who requires hand-holding, detailed project plans, or anything more than a somewhat ambiguous directive, you will have a very hard time here. Amazon hires smart people, gives them some concept of what they need to accomplish, and expects them to do the other 99%. That's not always a bad thing, but for some people, it's a nightmare. You must be able to execute on projects without a clear path forward, deal with complex problems which don't map 1:1 with your skillset, and learn to navigate a massively complex organization that is hurdling forward.
advice: Management is smart enough to figure this one out on their own.
pros: Amazon is an incredible place to work, filled with amazingly talented people. It is a place where new technology meets the salt of the earth work that happens in the fulfillment centers that drives the heart of the business. This unique situation is held together by core principles that permeate all levels of the company, from the top, to the bottom.When you work here, you will have the opportunity to take on…  as many challenges as you're willing to. There are few companies, tech, or otherwise, that will allow you to have almost free reign on their systems, processes, and standards. If you have the time, in addition to the work you are mandated, you have the ability to tackle any number of increasingly complex and mind-boggling challenging puzzles to solve. These take many forms, and can be incredibly rewarding, giving you experience in areas you never thought you would have. If you are someone who doesn't need direction, is self-starting and can get things done, quickly, there is limitless ability to challenge yourself at Amazon.Some teams are situated to take off, and if you get on the right one, at the right time, and have the necessary skillset, your life will suddenly feel like it's moving quicker than it used to. Time will pass instantly, and weeks turn to months before you realize what is happening. It's an incredible experience when this happens. Both in the field, and at corporate, this type of feeling is pervasive.Plan to be stretched regardless of the role you're in. Amazon is designed in such a way that the tasks that are given to you are almost too much for you to accomplish. You will need to be creative, take on partners, design new processes, and manage your time better than you thought humanly possible before coming on. You are in charge of your own work-life balance in the sense that you must know when to say 'slow down', or risk taking on too much and miss deliverables, this is frowned upon. Many of the reviews here fail to mention the employee responsibility in understanding their own workload, and being firm enough to push-back when it's exceeded their capacity. Most managers will understand this, and help you manage your workload if it exceeds what they think you can hit. That doesn't mean you won't have a tremendous amount to do, it means you need to know when to say enough or re-prioritize what it is you are working on. There is a tendency to take on too much, and burn out, you must insulate yourself from that process.There's a huge demand here for the ability to get things done quickly and efficiently. Amazon has not fostered an academic work environment. You will need to work with the information you have, or can quickly dig up, and make incredibly powerful and critical decisions with what would otherwise be considered ambiguous information. This is where it gets tricky, the principles of 'are right a lot' could be replaced with the more common having 'good instincts'. Having good instincts is a mixture of both learning while at the company, and your skills when you come in. If you don't have good instincts, or don't trust your own judgement, you will have a very hard time at Amazon. That being said, you also have to be right, very often - or rapidly learn from your mistakes and improve. This fast, iterative, learning, is part of what makes Amazon difficult to work at, but also why employees who can hang on for some time are highly regarded and needed to keep on to keep the business from repeating prior mistakes.

cons: The way the limited breaks are set up are bad. You don't get the full time.
advice: Keep on doing what you're doing!
pros: The managers are awesome and the pay is nice!

cons: For those that want to put their feet up or meander through every work day this is not the place for you. You will be expected to work hard and accomplish a lot.
pros: If you are someone who likes challenging, fast-paced environments with the autonomy to approach your goals in your own way, then this will be where you want to go.I love working here because every day is a new and rewarding challenge and there is always more to be done so you are never bored. Work-Life balance is definitely achievable but you need to set expectations around that and stick to them. No one is g… oing to hold your hand here you are in control of your own situation. That doesn't mean others won't help (they definitely will) you simply need to be the one reaching out and speaking up because they have just as much on their plates as you do.

cons: Expected to take part in an oncall cycle, whereby you can be paged to sign in and address an issue 24/7 for two weeks at a time (on most teams).
advice: The goal-focused approach will often go way too far. Latency improvements, while yes, are important to the customer, are many times not worth the amount of effort and sloppy experiments that get done just to meet a goal with upper management. We could be working on a cool new feature that people will actually use, but instead work for months at a time to shave 50 milliseconds off the page load time for 10% of custome… rs. Seems like a waste.
pros: I work on the Amazon Retail Website. Get to work on a wide spectrum of issues. Generally receive praise for good work.
